text: I have always been interested in understanding the purpose of things and how they are engineered to serve that purpose, whether organic or inorganic. The brain is a fascinating organ that we all possess; it is an infinitely powerful machine from which intelligence and cognition arise. We haven't even scratched the surface of understanding it.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It took me a while to connect studying and building technology to understanding the brain, not until graduate school. There were key moments in my life that influenced my trajectory. One significant moment was growing up with both sides of my family, where my grandparents suffered from a severe form of Alzheimer's. It's an incredibly debilitating condition, and I witnessed someone's entire identity and mind deteriorating over time. I remember thinking about the power of the mind and its fragility.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It's fascinating how losing a sense of identity can reveal the power of the brain. Much of what we know about the brain comes from cases of trauma that result in the loss of certain abilities. These cases help us understand the critical functions of specific brain tissues. The brain is an incredibly fragile organ, yet it is also remarkably plastic and resilient. The term "plastic" refers to its adaptability.

Another key moment that influenced the trajectory of my life occurred during my teenage years when I came to the U.S. I didn't speak a word of English, which created a significant language barrier. I remember feeling isolated and unable to connect with those around me, so I spent a lot of time on my own, reading books and watching movies. I naturally gravitated towards these activities.
